Thanks for watching this video. I'm glad you're here. If you feel like this earns your subscription please click here: http://bit.ly/Subscribe2SED
How this happened: I messaged Tory "If you ever find yourself with an open lunch I'll buy. No cameras, just rocket geek chat."
A few months later he changed a flight one day so we could grab lunch, but he also carved out a couple of hours before lunch to give me a personal tour.
He's as cool off camera as he is on camera. He allowed me to ask any technical question I had, and I never even got close to the limits of his understanding of rockets. His technical prowess is something I aspire to. We made a video on the second channel where I interview him about more specific things about rockets, as well as how he feels about competitors.
2nd Channel Interview with Tory about rocket engines, competitors, and business philosophy: https://youtu.be/DQaPOIQLEUo
Hard work 💪💪💪💪

comment_text: While we wait for Musk's amazing Starship rocket, today's space program centrally depends on the original 1960s Mercury and Gemini rocket, Atlas and Titan. And we beg Russians for 1950s Soyuz to lift our heaviest loads. We use the ancient Mercury and Gemini, why not the newer and best, Apollo F-1 rocket? Why beg the Russians for their stronger rocket than our Gemini Titan? The Apollo F-1 remains the strongest rocket ever! F-1 the only 100% reliable rocket ever! 65 engines, 13 flights, zero F-1 failures! To the moon with five F-1 not 39 raptors, and no risky refueling in orbit! NASA planned the F-1 to take us to Mars by 1985, why didn't we use it? Why not now? With 39 F-1 we could do far MORE than Musk's Starship! Why did we waste 15 years waiting for the Shuttle rocket? A weak hydrogen burner needing solid fuel boosters. We could have launched Shuttle on 2 or 3 F-1. Why did we wait 60 years for Musk, Bezos and ULA to replace the Apollo F-1? We centrally use old '60s Mercury, Gemini, we discard America's best, Apollo and use Russian Soyuz. And old late 60s Shuttle weak hydrogen rocket is now back on the new SLS to take us back to the moon - weak, so with solid fuel boosters. Why not use the tested and proved, 100% reliable F-1 that already took us to the moon? What is the hidden scandal of the F-1 that it's the only '60s rocket we don't use? Our strongest, that took humans the farthest. The F-1 was plagued with explosions early on. Oscillations, but engineers found a way to make them "self-correct" almost magically! I wish we had that magical rocket for the last 60 years. And even today. We use the older Mercury and Gemini but quietly stop using the perfect record, best, strongest Apollo! Why? While we wait for Musk, Bezos and ULA with their less good rockets than 60 years ago! The F-1 became the most reliable, strongest rocket ever. Raptors have failed. F-1 never failed once going to the moon and is stronger! Is this the scandal Neal Armstrong meant in his moon landing anniversary, last speech: "Things left undone," "protected by truth's protective layers." Maybe the F-1 that powered the moon flights has some hidden scandal. What else could be left undone, protected by truth's protective layers? Going to the moon/Mars would be more urgent. If people thought no one had been there before. Do we want the real 1st people on the moon to be communist Chinese or invading brutish Russians? The race would be back on!

With the exception of some types of engineering planning and surgery, an interesting thing about most (even specialized) jobs is that, with training, most individuals (with a decent iq) can be trained to perform perfectly fine in two weeks.
i remember when i was working as a pharm D intern, i had to turn even the most basic questions over to "be handled by" the pharmacist... pure ego...
"So, does this med come in pill form?" "Hold on one sec and I'll get the pharmacist for you."

i think my parents were 99% right when they elucidated that getting a degree simply lets employers know how stable you are as a... ya'know... tool.
Any information needed today is widely available, so in-depth learning isn't so much a thing one needs to gain anymore. Even when someone does learn a bunch, they WILL forget it. Furthermore, it will rarely be intuitive understanding and won't matter on a functional front.



...just cathartic musing, i guess...

44:28 That's something incredible I didn't even think about, but yes. Getting to know the people who are going to use it, makes you much more careful and caring about the parts you're making. As you care more about people who have a "human side" in your mind, than just faces on a wall, or people you don't even know.
I'm surprised at how socializing is absolutely crucial to producing, good and safe cold-hard-emotionless products. It's made "with love", to put it in a corny, yet true way.

In my defense, as a programmer, I have little need for any social interaction as long as the code works, so this is very different to what I'm used to.

Starting in 1967 I worked for Convair at the  Kearny Mesa plant in San Diego, CA on the Atlas Centaur program. The original Atlas rockets which predated Centaur were ICBM's and made by the same welded stainless steel process that is used on the current Centaur rockets. Basically, the rockets were flying gas tanks. The tanks were either kept pressurized or stretched in a special cradle that fastened to each end of the rocket to keep the  tanks from collapsing and there were special trailers that kept the tanks stretched while being transported to their destination. The machine that did the stainless steel seam welding was a modified spot welder that used an rolling electrode wheel to give a contiguous welded joint. Another interesting thing about the Atlas SLV was that there were 3 engines, the center that could gimbal for steering and the outer 2 engines that were jettisoned after the boost phase to lighten the load.

I feel bad for Tory. He’s smart and seems like a genuinely good guy but he’s handcuffed by his bosses. Even though he’s the CEO, ULA is a wholly owned joint venture between Boeing and Lockheed Martin and they don’t care about innovating or investing in the future. The parent companies just squeeze every dollar of profit they can and Tory’s left without the necessary funds to pursue any novel ideas. In a few more years, ULA will be little more than a dried up husk, kept on life support by the occasional military launch. All these new launch companies are coming online very soon. Astra, Firefly, Relativity. Rocket Lab is developing a medium lift launcher. And then there’s SpaceX, who is absolutely destroying the OldSpace dinosaurs.

I toured the plant with my husband. Our son who works at ULA was able to get us a tour and it was one of the best times of our lives:)!! We adore rockets:)!  All things enormous, that burn thousands of pounds of fuel in seconds and blast off into space dropping boosters, etc.  My dreams come true:)! We are so happy that our son has this opportunity and he loves it just like Mom:)!  Since he was little the two of us would jump into simulators and anything that pretended to take us to the stars:)!  When he went to work at ULA it was as much of a dream come true for me as him.  CEO Tony Bruno did a great job giving this tour:)!  I saved it and will definitely be watching this over and over:)!  I grew up when anything with Nasa/space took the front page for weeks and was the top news story.  My Dad and I talked about all of the advances being made and we dreamed the dream of space exploration.  My Dad is 87 now a Great, Grandfather so proud of his grandson and we now talk about all the latest rockets that are coming out. We talk about how they help our country/humanity and marvel that one of our family is involved in this fascinating and exciting world:)!!!  Family of rocket lovers here:)!!! Thank you ULA for being so COOL😎!!!! Raising up three more Grandsons, little rocket fellas:)!!! Sat and watched around six or more videos this afternoon of a Heavy, Atlas and others blasting off with two of the grandsons and they were literally jumping up and down watching them "shoot into space"!!! Made me so happy:). My son, his wife and two of the grandsons have been too Switzerland twice learning all there is to know and our son has met real astronauts:)!!!!!! Seriously, you find a more exciting job than this let me know. . .  I told my son if I was younger I would work in the broom closet:)!!!!  Words like rocket, orbital, burn, mega ton, boosters, helium, Mars, entry,  fairings, all of these and so, so many more are like chips for me, can't stop with just one:)!!!! Super video, thanks.  I subscribed.  You did a great job asking great questions and camera work showing how beautiful ULA really is.

My uncle was a rocket scientist so this video is especially interesting to me.
We were never allowed to know what he actually did or what all he worked on during his career. We still don’t know.
I do know he was on the team that developed something for the engines for Challenger. My grandma always said he was involved in developing the fuel but I don’t really know. I also don’t really know why I’m writing this all out on the internet for everyone to see... anyway, My understanding is that he was present during the call to NASA warning them not to launch Challenger until the temperature outside raised to at least temperature IDK because Below temperature IDK, certain seals would have shrunken enough to be out of spec. The MC said the rocket technology was not avilable to the general public.  “On contrare “.  I worked at one of the OEMs in the 80s that was the first company to use solid propellant gas generators for PASSENGER airbags that were introduced in the 1989 Ford Continental.  There were many companies involved in the 1980s effort to put airbags in vehicles which turned out to be the technology that continues to this day.   Safety finally sold.  GM tried in the early 70s but they offered an optional system and dealer marketing support was abysmal and corporate was not much better.  This effort was lead by Ed Cole.  It was a one man show.  He didn’t get much corporate support so the program died.  In the 10 off years a small group of engineers across town (as few as 2 in a bad sales year) kept looking at ways to enhance upon airbag design.  Previous suppliers were helpful but skeptical.  Eaton had made a big investment and got thrown under the bus.  They declined to participate. Many small rocket motor and speciality devices companies were interested.  Military and aerospace budgets were being cut.  I got to visit places that 10 years previous I could only see through binoculars.  I ended up with a design responsibility  for a component that could be made common  across many application.  It was an electro explosive device.  Where do I start?   I got a lot of help from many of the suppliers to the military and aerospace industry and used a modified existing design and my engineering spec was patterned after military specifications.  I would be asked, “how do you know that the spec is good enough?”.  My response,” I used an existing spec developed for MAN RATED SYSTEMS  that would go into orbit and to the moon”.  That seemed to be adequate.  It was a great experience.  I got to meet 2 scientists from the Franklin Research Center when it was in Philadelphia.  Their claim to fame was hardening the electronics against electro magnetic and radio frequency interference.  They had some wild tests done at White Sands Air Force base.  They would get a radar dish pointed at a vehicle equipped with special instruments and irradiate it with 100 watts/ meter squared which was considered the upper level of human tolerance at the time.  Measurements would show if any of that power got into the airbag wiring.  A little bit did but not enough to initiate or degrade the device.  Old engineers love to tell their war stories.  With us going back into the rocket business we get a whole new generation of rocketeers.

This will be buried. Anyway, I work for a small growing military contractor that builds custom Linux distro's for the US Army's battle hardware. The reason I chose this company to work for is because top down to bottom, they're all former or current engineers. I had worked for conglomerates run by bean counters and every day was an illogical decision to meet some irrelevant goal. They spent more dimes trying to save a penny rather than letting knowledgeable people, like Tory here, (whom also understands the work force is made of people and not try to negotiate a squeeze), make the decisions. ULA is being operated as an engineering company by engineers. It's why they are successful.

There are so many things to think about when putting rockets together for specific purposes.... weight, strength, efficiency, stuctural integrity, properties of the metal and how that can change, weld strength and integrity, permeability of the metal, reactivity of metals, oxidation and so on.
It's easy to see why the tolerances have to be so tight!
This isn't exactly a homemade rocket made from a paper towel roll and balsa wood fins (although those are absolutely a LOT of fun and a great place to start!!!)

I worked at KSC for 10 years on many "vehicles" 2 of them I can tell you about were the Boeing IUS assembly and launch, and the Shuttle doing vertical integration, launch pad close out, etc. What most people don't know is solid propellant is explosive. Usually with classification of 1.1 to 1.3 Highly explosive. The space shuttle also used fuels called hypergols with are extremely dangerous if you breathe or come in contact with. They leaked all the time because the fuel and oxidizer are corrosive. When they come together, there is a chemical reaction that combusts. It was used on the small little rockets all over the shuttle (Reaction control) to change the attitude of the vehicle, and the Ohms engines as well.

Amazing tour! Tory appears to be so calm concerning his responsibility of providing state-of-the-art rockets to meet the standards necessary to accomplish complex missions. However, his facility is equipped with the technology and staff to build light-weight yet strong vehicles 1.5 times the standards of base capabilities. Talk about "close-tolerances," my God...that alone is remarkable! Each stage of the fuel tanks to be combined with the power-plant section is flawless and built to withstand all the temperatures and pressures each rocket will encounter in flight. What is quite interesting is "mating" the aluminum panels with that type of welding, if you can call it that, stronger at the mating surfaces than the surrounding strength of the material itself. Add to that is mating it to the cargo stage, built of steel, and soon to be equipped for a human flight! Yet, in the center of this massive operation is Tory! He is responsible for it all and talking to him is like talking to your brother. Wow!

The sheer amount of human intellectual inventory stored at NASA installations, like Johnson and Houston Space Centers, is STAGGERING.

I believe everyone should have to learn the basics of critical thinking and scientific literacy in elementary school, just to inoculate as much of the population against charlatans and any other BS as possible, in their lives.

So we can make better informed decisions, from day to day experiences to voting and what little emergency management we might encounter, in the future.

But, that's just for anyone to become a contributing member of society.

Learning even a fraction of the information at places like this is always a bonus, additional information should ALWAYS be encouraged.

That's why these videos on this channel, and many others like it, are SO extremely valuable.

Especially in this "anti-intellectual" era we're unfortunately going through recently. When, for some reason, some people think it's cool to be against science and education.

Clearly breeding an environment in which Fake News and false information can be so widespread and pervasive.

If everyone valued equally the benefits of basic fundamental scientific literacy, maybe we'd have more of a chance of actually leading the World again, instead of allowing other Countries to advance beyond us.

The discoveries yet to be made by human beings isn't reserved for one particular Nation or another, knowledge and understanding doesn't care what flag you fly.

That's why, the world's largest science experiment right now is in Switzerland, instead of the United States, which is where it would have been had Congress not voted down the funding for the Supermassive Supercollider.

We would have discovered the Higgs Boson DECADES earlier, instead of resting on our laurels and thinking we're SO advanced just skating by on our Apollo program achievements half a Century later.

Now, Europe has the World's largest Particle accelerator, and China has the World's largest Radio Telescope.

We need to grab the reigns again for ourselves if we plan to be anything more than customers to the rest of the World's products, in the future.

If we slow down, we may as well be moving backwards, because that's exactly what we look like to everyone else anyway as they pass us by.

Anodizing is NOT a plating process!
Amazing video, but that part bugged me as I work in both sides of the metal finishing industry.

Plating adds some kind of metal onto another surface by passing DC though solution with a metal salt dissolved in it. The part is the cathode.

Anodizing is a controlled form of electrolytic corrosion that creates a honeycomb pore structure in the surface by passing DC through it while suspended in an acid. Itis highly corrosion resistant. It does not add material to the part as in a plating process.

The two processes are quite literally polar opposites.

Does the friction stir welding not locally compromise the anodising?

Looking at that assembled tank section drives home that the majority of the weight of the tank is seemingly to resist buckling caused by the mass of the rocket. There's no reinforcement of isogrid or orthogrid over the welds, so clearly just the solid aluminium sheet in that low thickness is enough to resist the hoop stress from the internal pressure of the fluid in the tank. Which means all the grid must be to resist buckling under the vertical forces from above, and explains why the newer grid with the bias towards vertical stress is more efficient. Very cool.

I did some friction stir welding myself by taking a bad carbide end mill and grinding it until it's just a bit with a small bob in the center (I used a dremel with a diamond wheel, spun it in my milling machine and advancing the table ever so slightly). Then I was able to friction stir weld aluminum together. I only did this with plate aluminum and it requires very solid clamping, you are essentially running an end mill that has no flute, at very high RPM right into a piece of aluminum. A lot of CNC guys do this by accident (like spin a 4 flute end mill extremely fast into aluminum without coolant, instant friction stir weld).



When it works it was actually easier to do than TIG welding or any other welding since you don't have to sit there and worry about current setting, flux, gas mix, etc. and it just produces very clean welds. But you need a really rigid milling machine, that can have as high of an RPM as you can get it.

I'm way past retirement age. I grew up in Alabama. I can tell y'all from personal experience that NASA and rocket engineering has been part of Alabama's legacy since I was in grade school. It's true that North Alabama is at the tip of the Appalachia, the home of the stereotypical "dumb hillbilly." But, to be clear, this video is talking about rocket scientists from the same place. I've travelled. I've heard people the world over refer to Alabamians as dumb country hicks all my life. These same people use the expression, "It's not rocket science", meaning it's not above their understanding.

Both the rocket scientists and the hillbillies are from North Alabama! They are one and the same. These so-called "dumb" Alabama "hillbillies" are some of the smartest people on earth. Some are black, some white, some female, some male, some young, some old. They've been building the world's most sophisticated spacecraft for generations and they are all Alabamians. You may call them hillbillies but you can't call them "dumb."

At 10:30 they are talking about "safety factors" built-in over and above the maximum stress the thing is tested to break at. I remember from back in the 1960s regarding Cessna single-engine airplanes we were taught that the aircraft was designed to take at least 3.8 Gs for stress in the "normal category" before something might break, not necessarily a wing. Then we were told there was a 15% safety factor built into those numbers. That was always reassuring to know when a wind gust caused our heads to hit the roof on a rare occasion.

Where would we be without geeks?! Best space related video/documentary I have ever seen! Extremely knowledgeable CEO. I grew up near Aerojet in Folsom CA. and witnessed the Space Shuttle rockets being tested from only a half mile away literally. They were so loud at a mile out that the schools in the area would let students out to watch and listen, since they would disrupt class anyways. From where I stood to watch, I heard the warning sirens, then the 15 second countdown over loud speakers. When the rocket ignited, it was silent, but I saw the shock wave going out in every direction across the tall grasslands. When it reached me, it was as if I was standing in the middle of a huge vibrating football game board. My vision went blurred, and I had to hold my hands over my ears. The sound was shaking every cell in my body. It was a full 90 second burn.
So, to see this documentary was very cool. Thank you!

Great video and a very enlightening tour of Decatur.  I find it interesting how Tory keeps mention how this or that is the most high performance engine or stage, etc.  He doesn't seem to have learned that reliability and cost is more important than performance.  SpaceX can hit all the same reference orbits or interplanetary trajectories with Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy.  Neither is a "high tech" or has more efficient engines.  They still get the job done and for a lower cost.  Also, all these new production systems and cost savings are borne from the competition from SpaceX.  ULA was happy to keep doing the same thing without innovating or making more than token efforts at cost reduction until they were forced to by the competition.

Man, this is almost the same the process I used to build my first rocket in my backyard when I was 8. Of course, there were some small differences; I used cardboard and wrapped alfoil around it for the body of the rocket. The nozell was made out of a tin can (sans top) with holes poked through at geometrically predetermined intervals (random poking) and the cone was made out of more aluminium-plated cardboard.
Of course, MY rocket wasn't pressurised, or capable of holding any pressure above/ below STP and an accident during a testing phase caused my whole rocket to go up in kerosene-powered flames, but aside from those minor differences, the process appears to be exactly the same...

As a mechanical engineer (never in rocketry, tho, except in my dreams), this was a spectacular video. One of the most interesting I've ever watched.

Something that you might be able to relate to, now, is the fact that Tomahawk cruise missiles have no fuel tanks, and also (like Centaur) cannot support their own weight without support. The skin is between 0.0005" thick & 0.012" thick (at the "hard points"). The entire body of the missile is the fuel tank, with the electronics immersed in the fuel.

When they fill it with fuel, they pressurize it & seal it. It is, in essence, a thin steel (I believe) balloon.

For most of the body of the missile (the thin sections), the walls are so thin that they cannot support any differential stress across its thickness. One demonstration that used to be given to VIPs was to have the pressurized body of (I assume a rejected part) in what looked like a hand ball court, which had a bunch of netting hanging from the ceiling.

They'd give the VIP a hard hat, goggles & a sledge hammer, & invite him to hit the side of the missile as hard as he could (or dared).

The result was amazing. The sledge hit the side, which collapsed just like a balloon would. Then the side (& hammer) rebounded. The sledge hammer would end up in the netting above their heads. And the side of the missile would be completely unmarked by the hammer blow.

No stress across the thickness of the material, no strain, no residual deformation.

I was a news photographer years ago and worked around law enforcement and rescue personnel, often going on ride alongs. I asked from time to time if I could ever get a ride on the SAR helicopters that the county operated. Pretty much everyone said no, no one gets to do that.
Then one day I did an assignment that involved the head honcho at the air unit. Hit it off and got to talking. Turns out he had seen, and apparently liked, much of my work with LE and rescue. When saying our goodbyes he casually mentioned that I should come to the air unit hangar and go up on a mission some time. Couldnt believe it!
1 week later I was in the air watching the finest pilots and crew members do their thing while getting unprecedented access to the men, machines and facilities.
By the end of the day my face hurt from smiling. That kind of special access is thrilling in a way that is indescribable. I just hope I asked 1 or 2 questions half as on point as Destin's.
This ULA tour is truly next level. Congrats on getting to where you are brother. You've earned it!

What we observe as space are the stars (lights in the sky), sun, moon, and wandering stars. These bodies in our sky are contained in the firmament. The firmament is a barrier, or dome which is responsible for our atmospheric pressure. No rocket has or ever will penetrate through this firmament. This is where we observe the famous arc of all the rocket flight paths in every launch. Thanks to NASA’s decades long indoctrination of a fake space reality, we’re all programmed to think of space as the heliocentric model of a spinning ball earth and other planets revolving around the sun in a galaxy, in an endless vacuum of space. Space in the heliocentric model does not exist and is a false reality created by Hollywood’s science fiction movies of Star Wars, Star Trek, etc, NASA is Hollywood but with a larger budget. The heliocentric model is false and our reality is a flat plane that is stationary with the firmament above. Up is up and down is down. Space is cool but we have to reprogram our thinking to reject the false heliocentric model version of space and think in terms of space as what is contained inside the firmament. Beyond or outside the firmament is where God’s throne exists in the third heaven: Biblical Cosmology. I am yet to see any observable evidence of earth’s curvature to prove NASA’s version of a spinning globe. I am yet to see a rocket launch (observing from the ground) traveling straight up and disappearing into the daytime or nighttime sky with no arc in its flight path. Lol at the people that got triggered and didn’t understand what the guy meant when he said that a factor of safety was a factor or ignorance. He wasn’t insulting anybody, he was talking about ignorance in a general sense, not specifically in a human sense. For example car manufacturers don’t know what exact conditions each car will face after it’s out of the assembly line so they have to incorporate safety factors to try and deal with all those unknowns (ignorance). Also that’s why cars built for very specific controlled purposes like F1 cars and the like have far tighter tolerances and less “safety factors” than a road car. Those cars are built for very specific conditions and only need enough safety factors to meet any regulations required and to be able to perform its duty correctly.

In the case of rockets, there’s strict monitoring of every parameter leading up to a launch and after it. So unless it’s under ideal conditions a launch won’t happen. So as long as they’re accurate and consistent with their safety factors there shouldn’t be any surprises that can’t be dealt with.

Amazing they bend the metal after machining the isogrids.  I would have thought the ribs in the grid would buckle when the plate was being bent.  I thought that bending was exactly what the grid is there to resist.  So what other function exactly does it serve?  What forces does it resist to allow the part to be thinner and lighter than if it was just flat metal bent into the same curve?

I absolutely LOVED this video.  I've always wondered what the manufacturing process behind these incredible machines is like, and it DID NOT DISAPPOINT!  As someone who has spent a comparably tiny amount of time around machining tools, it  fascinates me that these craftspeople are using tools and techniques that I've learned but with such incredible quantities, and precision.  I've done milling, forming, etching, and welding, but only ever on jewelry, and it's so incredible to see these same techniques that have existed for thousands of years are not only still alive today, but also critical to our exploration of space.  Humans are absolutely incredible, and it's so inspiring to see how just increasing tolerances and precision can get you from making a tankard to making a rocket.  Same techniques, but orders of magnitude different in scale and precision.  So cool!  Thank for this video, Destin, and thanks to Tory for allowing you to share it with us!

First lets explain who ULA actually is: Founders: Lockheed Martin · Boeing, 2 major US Government contracted military contractors.  Oh, did I leave out the word "bloated"?  These company's have in the past build incredible tech products, but at a hugely inflated cost to the American Taxpayer.  Now that they are having to compete with independent commercial contractors, the corners they are cutting to meet budgets are causing failures. One reason they were NOT selected for the first American Crewed Launch to the ISS.  If it weren't for an institutional history of political kickbacks, lobbing and corruption, Boeing and Lockheed could be doing much better work. I hope they find their way and do so.  Their expertise is needed.

27:36 As someone who runs a chemical processing shop, this is awesome.
A bit more on anodising:
It's not actually a plating process, since it doesn't deposit anything onto your part. It's a chemical conversion process because you are converting what is already there (aluminum in this case, though there are other metals that can be anodised) into a different chemical (aluminum oxide).

Honestly I'm guilty of being very into the spectacle of Space-X rocket launches, they've definitely brought excitement back to space like the Shuttle launches used to, with their great onboard cameras and coverage.

It's easy to see ULA as some entrenched over-priced provider, but seeing this and the secondary video (where he talks about competitors) has given me a whole different view and respect for ULA.

CEOs often seem to come and go, they seem interchangeable or maybe have some sort of specialized knowledge of the market. But to watch Tory be so knowledgeable about every stage of their production, not just talking points or buzzwords, but understanding core engineering reasons for it, and seemingly very well liked by his staff, has totally flipped my view of the company.

I already watched their launches anyway, but now I'm looking forward to seeing the first Vulcan launch with the same excitement I had for Falcon Heavy.

Thanks to Mr. Bruno for showing off his awesome factory. His pride was evident and justified. As an American, I am proud of all those wonderful Alabama employees making machines that fly into space. When I was a kid, I was a Titan Launch Crew Commander and always wondered how those airframes were made.

Very cool, wish I'd thought of going into the space business, when I was a high school lad, we managed to launch a small payload 4 miles high. Had we staged our liquid propellant rocket and our solid propellant rocket we could have done much better than 4 miles. Rocket "safety officer" meaning Dad, did not permit us to go any higher. Not after the NY State police showed up after we launched one of our high powered amateur rockets out over Lake Ontario. Dad lost his nerve to push the envelope. The police were not wise to what we haddone as they responded to a citizen complaint that saw a fireball heading out over the lake moving at high speed and they also heard the rocket breaking the sound barrier as the thrust tapered off close to burnout. We were using spun fiberglass and spun carbon fiber tubing and graphite ceramic nozzles in 1969 long before carbon fiber was as common as today. A neighbor was an engineer for Spaulding Fibre in Western NY and we had bits and pieces tubing to our specs and tech data on their experimental tubing. Low carbon steel had been our material, much safer with composites than steel and easier to work with, pouring 2 part epoxy resins and inserting carbon/ceramic nozzles. Our liquid fuel rocket had a stainless steel un-cooled combustion chamber and nozzle and the tanks were made of aluminium and pressurized with dry ice. The oxidizer was nitric acid and the fuel was an 80/20 mix of turpentine and furfuryl alcohol. Static tested a couple of times to find minimum furfuryl that gave reliable ignition, flown once, the parachute failed. The Isp of about 240 seconds  only a little higher than our solid propellants about 220 seconds. Great fun, I did the math and design, my shop skilled buddy did the machining with the help of his shop teacher. Great fun ... learned a lot. Neighbor on one side of us worked for the fibre company and on the other side of my parents house another engineer for Bell Aerospace and assigned to the RM-81 Agena  B in the 1960's. I had plenty of expert help, learned how to do stress / strain calculations along with Algebra 2 and Trig for the NY Reagents exam. If anything school math was neglected during a wild construction project. I still crammed and passed the reagents at the end of the school year. A month after school let out Armstrong landed on the Moon, I felt let down, I know how the Soviets must have felt we both lost the space race.

I thought of a triangle and I never went to a big name university but I have crossed many bridges. I worked in science and research my whole working life, and because I never lost my need in understanding how things work my evenings, and weekends, were for study. This was not required to do an average job, but what I got for investing my time helped make my time spent at work more than only a paycheck. For some reason I do not understand, most of those big name school PhD's were annoyed by my self study program and that I took their slogan: "work smarter" to heart. One program of study was learn how to program the computer to do computer simulations of physical chemistry properties of mixtures. Not as complicated as "climate modeling" or weather forecasting next month but still a challenge to make useful estimations and reduce the number and increase the quality of Edison guesses in the lab.

The fact that the iso-grid machining has a triangle pattern because of computation limits in the 90s is pretty interesting (seen at 9:32). It's the same reason why the first stealth aircrafts like the F-117 Nighthawk had this rectangular/triangular shape: the software they used to calculate radar reflections could only deal with simple triangle shapes. You can read about this in Ben R. Rich's book "Skunk Works".

I've watched the entire video Destin. Thank you so much for sharing this with us. Through you, engineering students like me get to experience these amazing things out there in the world and recognize what we learn in the classroom in real world examples. In this video I saw Material science and material inspection, work hardening/strain hardening, Large scale CNC applications, robotic/human inspection, Stress analysis and geometric design for high pressure applications, Anodization, and an idea of how small the tolerances on high performance rocketry is. *Half a dime thick*. Goodness.

With the things I understood, there were a few things I don't understand, or have never heard of that I now know I can go out to look for and learn (like ring stress, which was new to me and I had never heard of it, unless it was taught to me under a different name).

This was an absolutely fantastic tour and technical discussion!! Thank you Destin!! The manufacturing of the Atlas and Vulcan is a very interesting process. The one thing that stands out--aside from all of the quality control and automation--is the incredible amount of aluminum that are fabricated into tanks and barrels. Although a huge amount of the machined material is reclaimed, there is an astounding amount of finished product that ends up at the bottom of the ocean for every flight (what an incredible waste of material).  Tory Bruno was a terrific technical guide for this tour. Thank you! I really enjoyed this tour.

THIS WAS ALMOST AN ORGASMIC MOMENT. I'M 78 YRS OLD AND HAVE BEEN A ROCKET NUT AS LONG AS I CAN RECALL. I REMEMBER WRAPPING TINFOIL AROUND A PENCIL FORMING MY ROCKET SHELL THEN CUTTING THE HEADS FROM MATCHES AND PACKING THEM IN THE SHELL. I ALWAYS HAD TROUBLE GETTING THE FINS TO STAY ATTACHED. HAD MANY 'FLIGHTS' EXPLODE ON THE 'PAD' AND A COUPLE TO MAYBE 20'. THEN I GRADUATED TO CUTTING SHOTGUN SHELLS AND PACKING THE POWDER INTO ACTUAL ALUMINUM TUBES. I CAN'T BELIEVE I STILL HAVE 10 FINGERS

That centaur that is a DEC, Dual Engine Centaur, will likely not carry astronauts to space, it is highly likely that CST-100 will be required to fly yet another test flight to verify its flight worthiness

The reason they're using the twin-engine Centaur upper stage for the crewed launches is for the safety of the crew if there's an abort.
Launch profile for the single-engine upper stage has the rocket ascending more steeply, to give the lower-powered single engine second stage time to circularize the orbit. But if a crewed capsule had to abort, it would reenter the atmosphere so steeply that the g-forces would be dangerous to the crew.
Twin engine upper stage lets them use a shallower launch profile, which would result in a more gradual and safer reentry if the capsule needs to abort during launch.

I hope they recycle the aluminum they remove from the sheets they receive. As for the strength pattern being different today than they were in the past: well, it is the same reason the first stealth planes like the F-114 Nighthawk had all those flat triangular areas vs. today's planes like the F-22 and F-35 looking much more sleek while being just as stealthy. Older computers simply didn't have the processing power to calculate complex curved spaces in relation to radar reflection compared to today's massively increased and ever increasing computing power. Just think of your smartphone. The first one came out in 2007 as the first iPhone. Now, just 13 years later our phones are many times more powerful and capable. Just yesterday I paid at a shop using my phone for the first time while also shooting full 4k video all using a device no thicker than a thin slice of bread. Truly amazing I think

I retired from ULA about 3 years ago. I worked on the plant from its inception. 
The plant was originally built by Boeing for Delta IV booster cores. As Tory eluded the factory was built to support a build rate much higher than current launch rates. I think the Boeing marketing guys were a little too optimistic. But those of us involved in designing a rocket factory went with those marching orders. It became apparent that we had over capacity early on. 
So at Boeing we reconfigured the factory to also build Delta IV upper stages and payload fairings. Then we transitioned Delta II production from Pueblo, Colorado to Decatur. When ULA was formed the decision was made to also move Atlas V production to Decatur. I remember when the factory site was just a red dirt field. It was amazing to be part of the factory development. It is an amazing factory. I interact with Tory much more now on Twitter as a retiree than I ever did as an employee. However I did work with Shannon on Commercial Crew. Go Vulcan!
Now you'll have to tour the ULA Harlingen, Texas plant where they build Payload Fairings and Payload Attach Assemblies.

Very cool. I am fortunate enough to be a contractor at the ULA facility in Harlingen Texas. I assist my friend Dennis Dubose in the logo painting on the 4 meter fairing that is produced there. As the fairing is ribbed, the logos need to be hand painted. Check out the video titled Rock(et) Stars 4-Meter Logo Painting on ULA's YouTube channel if you get a minute. And yes, cameras are strictly forbidden without permission. We have met Mr. Bruno briefly on a couple of occasions. Super nice guy. This isn't  my full time gig, but having grown up in Houston during the Apollo years, I have always been a space geek and make time in my schedule to go assist on these. It is an extremely interesting place to work.
